ar.q1: What is augmented reality (AR) and how do we use it here?
ar.a1: Augmented reality is a technology that allows you to see digital elements—such as characters, objects, or scenes—overlaid on the real environment through your phone’s camera. In this game, it’s used to see Roc, collect meteorite fragments, and view the discoveries.
ar.q2: Do I need to download any app?
ar.a2: No. This is a web application (webapp): you just need to access the link through your browser (Chrome, Safari...). Nothing needs to be downloaded.
ar.q3: Is my phone compatible with AR?
ar.a3: It works with most recent devices that have a camera and an updated browser. You need to allow camera access. If you have issues, try another browser or device.
ar.q4: I see nothing when I open the camera. What can I do?
ar.a4:
Make sure that:

● You have physically reached the correct point on the map (geolocation).
● You have granted camera access.
● There is enough light around.
If it still doesn't work, close and reopen the browser.
ar.q5: Is an internet connection required to use AR?
ar.a5: Yes. AR loads in the browser, so you need mobile data or Wi-Fi during the experience.
ar.q6: Is it safe to use AR while walking?
ar.a6: Yes, but be aware of your surroundings while using the camera. Don't walk looking at your phone and always keep an eye on your environment.
ar.q7: Can I take photos or videos with AR?
ar.a7: Yes! You can take screenshots and record videos with Roc and the different AR experiences and share them. It's a great way to remember and share your adventure.

game.q1: What is the goal of the game?
game.a1: The goal is to discover the six precious stones of Canyelles by completing augmented reality challenges. Throughout the route, you’ll need to collect meteorite fragments and obtain unique minerals.
game.q2: What’s the difference between a meteorite fragment and a discovery?
game.a2:
Meteorite fragments are natural elements that must be collected through interactive AR challenges.
Discoveries are the precious stones of Canyelles.
game.q3: How can I get meteorite fragments and precious stones?
game.a3: You must physically reach the geolocated points shown on the map. There, Roc will tell you a story and propose an interactive challenge and a question. If you succeed, you’ll obtain meteorite fragments and the precious stone associated with that point.
game.q4: What happens if I fail a challenge or a question?
game.a4: Interactive challenges are completed by collecting a specific number of meteorite fragments with AR. The challenge doesn’t end until you’ve collected them all—usually between six and seven. If you fail a question, the system asks you to try again.
game.q5: Do I need to register to play?
game.a5: Yes, registration is mandatory to participate in the game, access augmented reality points, and unlock meteorite fragments and precious stones. This allows us to save your progress, offer you a personalized experience, and ensure the system works properly. Registration is quick and only needs to be done once.
game.q6: Can I play in a group or with my family?
game.a6: Yes! The game is designed for group play: with friends, family, or school. You only need one phone or tablet per team and the desire to explore together.
game.q7: How long does the entire game take?
game.a7: It depends on your pace. The full route usually takes between 45 and 60 minutes, but you can complete it all at once or split it into several sessions.

map.q1: How does the game map work?
map.a1: The interactive map shows geolocated points along the route. AR content only unlocks when you physically reach a point.
map.q2: Is geolocation required on my phone?
map.a2:
Yes. Without geolocation enabled, you cannot play. The system needs to know your location to verify you've reached each point. We recommend turning on location before starting.

How to enable geolocation:

**On Android:**
1. Open your device settings.
2. Go to Location.
3. Enable Location.
4. Ensure your browser has location permissions:
   - Settings > Apps > [Browser Name] > Permissions > Location > Allow always or While using.

**On iPhone:**
1. Open Settings.
2. Go to Privacy & Security > Location Services.
3. Enable Location Services.
4. Check your browser settings (Safari or Chrome).
5. Ensure location is allowed during use.
map.q3: What if the map doesn't detect me correctly?
map.a3:
● Make sure your location is enabled (see steps above).
● Refresh your browser page.
map.q4: Is an internet connection required to use the map?
map.a4: Yes. The webapp needs an active connection to display the map and verify your location. However, data usage is very low.
map.q5: The map says I'm not at the right spot, but I am. What can I do?
map.a5:
● Move slightly around the area: sometimes GPS needs a few seconds.
● Ensure you're not under a structure or indoors.
● Make sure you have a good GPS or mobile signal.
map.q6: Can I do the route in any order?
map.a6: No. The route is linear. You must follow the established order of points since each challenge and finding depends on the previous point. The map will only show the next unlocked point—you can't proceed without completing the current one.

Volcano1Quiz1.title: Why did the railway become a key element for Bot when the front stabilized at the Ebro River?
Volcano1Quiz1.option1: Because it facilitated the rapid movement of troops and supplies to the rear
Volcano1Quiz1.option2: Because it allowed the evacuation of the civilian population to the coast
Volcano1Quiz1.option3: Because it connected directly with the Port of Alfacs
Volcano1Quiz1.option4: Because it served as an air-raid shelter for the population

Volcano1Quiz2.title: Who occupied the village of Bot on April 2, 1938?
Volcano1Quiz2.option1: Italian soldiers of the Littorio Division
Volcano1Quiz2.option2: German troops of the Condor Legion

Volcano1Quiz3.title: The engineers’ decision to disable a section of railway track on July 25, 1938 was mainly due to:
Volcano1Quiz3.option1: The need to halt the advance of the Army of the Ebro
Volcano1Quiz3.option2: A political order from the local government
Volcano1Quiz3.option3: An improvised action with no strategic value
Volcano1Quiz3.option4: A lack of materials to keep the line operational

Volcano2Quiz1.title: Why did Bot quickly become a key medical center during the Battle of the Ebro?
Volcano2Quiz1.option1: Because it was located just behind the front and could treat seriously wounded soldiers
Volcano2Quiz1.option2: Because it already had a large hospital before the war
Volcano2Quiz1.option3: Because it was far from the front and did not suffer bombardments
Volcano2Quiz1.option4: Because it had a nearby maritime station

Volcano2Quiz2.title: What role did the first-aid post play within the village’s medical organization?
Volcano2Quiz2.option1: To provide initial treatment and distribute the wounded to hospitals
Volcano2Quiz2.option2: To accommodate only lightly wounded soldiers
Volcano2Quiz2.option3: To serve as a medicine storage facility

Volcano2Quiz3.title: Which element best demonstrates the intensity of medical work from September 1938 onward?
Volcano2Quiz3.option1: The constant arrival of ambulances at the square
Volcano2Quiz3.option2: The presence of German soldiers in the village

Volcano3Quiz1.title: Why were assets such as mills, estates, or wine cellars confiscated in Bot during the first months of the war?
Volcano3Quiz1.option1: To reorganize life and ensure subsistence at a critical moment
Volcano3Quiz1.option3: To punish the entire population of the village
Volcano3Quiz1.option4: To prepare them as military facilities

Volcano3Quiz2.title: What does the creation of workers’ collectives indicate?
Volcano3Quiz2.option1: That shared solutions were sought in order to survive
Volcano3Quiz2.option2: That the village was left without authorities
Volcano3Quiz2.option3: That everyone agreed with the decisions made

Volcano3Quiz3.title: Why did the town council print municipal banknotes during the war?
Volcano3Quiz3.option1: To facilitate trade due to the lack of small change

Volcano4Quiz1.title: Why did the cemetery of Bot gain such importance during the war?
Volcano4Quiz1.option1: Because it was in the rear and many fallen soldiers were buried there
Volcano4Quiz1.option2: Because it was the oldest in the region
Volcano4Quiz1.option3: Because it was far from the front
Volcano4Quiz1.option4: Because there was a permanent hospital there

Volcano4Quiz2.title: What does the way soldiers were initially buried indicate?
Volcano4Quiz2.option1: That there was little time and many deaths
Volcano4Quiz2.option2: That it was a solemn tribute
Volcano4Quiz2.option3: That they were all local residents

Volcano4Quiz3.title: Why did it become necessary to adapt an agricultural estate as a new military necropolis?
Volcano4Quiz3.option1: Because the municipal cemetery could no longer accommodate more burials
Volcano4Quiz3.option3: To avoid bombardments of the cemetery

Volcano5Quiz1.title: Why did the Francoist regime accelerate the extension of the Val de Zafán railway in 1938?
Volcano5Quiz1.option1: To facilitate military transport in the occupied areas
Volcano5Quiz1.option4: To provide jobs for the local population

Volcano5Quiz2.title: Who were the Workers’ Battalions that worked on the railway line?
Volcano5Quiz2.option2: Specialized workers hired by the State

Volcano5Quiz3.title: What happened to the railway route once the war ended?
Volcano5Quiz3.option1: It was completed using forced labor
Volcano5Quiz3.option3: It was converted into a road
Volcano5Quiz3.option4: It was rebuilt only with free workers

intro.title1: This augmented reality experience requires access to your device’s camera and motion sensors.
intro.text1: Welcome to the game “Canyelles and the Story of the Meteorite.” Listen to Roc, a fragment of the meteorite that fell in Canyelles almost two hundred years ago.
intro.title2: This augmented reality experience requires access to your device’s camera and motion sensors.
intro.text2: Listen to Roc and find the meteorite pieces. Tap them to collect them.
intro.title3: This augmented reality experience requires access to your device’s camera and motion sensors.
intro.text3: Listen to Roc and throw the volcanic rocks into the volcanoes.
intro.text: I’m Miula, the owl of memory, and for a long time I have been flying over our coastline, keeping the stories hidden within it. Many years ago, during the Spanish Civil War, along the coast of Sitges, Vilanova i la Geltrú, Cubelles, Cunit, Calafell and El Vendrell, bunkers, trenches and fortifications were built to protect the towns from a possible attack from the sea. Today, these places help us understand history and what everyday life was like at that time, shaped by fear, waiting, collective organisation and the silences that many people had to keep in order to survive. If you join me, I will tell you the stories of each place and help you discover why they are so important to our collective memory. Your mission will be to help me deactivate old explosive devices using augmented reality. Once you succeed, I will ask you a question to check whether you have been paying attention to my explanations.​ If you answer correctly, you will receive a 3D collectible object related to the place you have just discovered. Are you ready?​ I’ll be waiting for you at the different points along the route. See you soon!

To maintain security and improve the services offered.
